user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of request_completed_callback:
```c
static void
request_completed_callback (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            void **req_cls,
                            enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct Request *request = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == request)
    return;
  if (NULL != request->session)
    request->session->rc--;
  if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
  free (request);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The function request_completed_callback does not call itself directly. The call to the external function MHD_destroy_post_processor is not evidence of indirect recursion by itself. Only if MHD_destroy_post_processor (or functions it calls) were documented/known to invoke request_completed_callback would an indirect self-call occur — there is no such evidence in the provided code fragment.
